definitions.definition: in or into the space separating two or more points, objects, people, etc.

examples.text: Q comes between P and R in the English alphabet.
I sat down between Jo and Diana.
Switzerland lies between France, Germany, Austria and Italy.
The paper had fallen down between the desk and the wall.
My job is somewhere between a secretary and a personal assistant.

definitions.definition: in the period of time that separates two days, years, events, etc.

examples.text: It's cheaper between 6 p.m. and 8 a.m.
Don't eat between meals.
Children must attend school between the ages of 5 and 16.
Many changes took place between the two world wars.

definitions.definition: at some point along a scale from one amount, weight, distance, etc. to another

examples.text: It weighed between nine and ten kilos.
The temperature remained between 25°C and 30°C all week.
the border between Sweden and Norway
We fly between Rome and Paris twice daily.

definitions.definition: used to show a connection or relationship

examples.text: a difference/distinction/contrast between two things
a link between unemployment and crime
There's a lot of bad feeling between them.
I had to choose between the two jobs.

definitions.definition: shared by two or more people or things

examples.text: We ate a pizza between us.
This is just **between you and me**/**between ourselves** *(= it is a secret)*.

definitions.definition: by putting together the efforts or actions of two or more people or groups

examples.text: We ought to be able to manage it between us.
China and India between them account for a third of the world's population.

definitions.definition: used to show that several activities are involved

examples.text: Between working full-time and taking care of the kids, he didn't have much time for hobbies.

wordOrigin: Old English betwēonum, from be ‘by’ + a Germanic word related to two.
